text: we've just seen on the Iraq inquiries
website a letter posted from the
chairman of the Iraq inquiry sir john
chilcot to the Prime Minister a letter
that was sent yesterday outlining the
timetable for the eventual publication
of his report you'll remember that this
has been a long time coming we learn in
this letter sent from sir john chilcot
to the Prime Minister that this whole
document should be published in june or
july of next year the whole report will
be completed we're told by the by the
middle of april but after that it will
be sent to national security for a
process of screening so we won't get to
see it until next summer by that stage
we will be what more than five years on
from the last person to give evidence
that such has been the longevity of the
process in pulling together all of the
information and to John and his team at
completing its work but we now do have
at least a timetable yeah and just tell
us again what this what Chilcott has
been looking at all this time yeah a
huge amount is what he's been looking at
so way back in 2009 the 15th of june
2009 then Prime Minister Gordon Brown
said that there was a necessity to set
up an inquiry that would look into all
of the lessons that could be learned
from the Iraq war over a huge time
period 2001 to 2009 looking at the build
up to the Iraq war where the troops were
properly trained and equipped and then
looking at the aftermath of the war
itself the beginnings of the process of
gathering evidence then began with all
sorts of leading lights from the New
Labour era and senior voices from the
Foreign Office and elsewhere giving
evidence in public the last evidence
session was on the second of februari
2011 and at the time we were told by Sir
John that it would be quote some months
before the final report that would be
published I've just been doing right
sums it is 56 months since that point
and we have another seven or eight
months to wait until we actually see it
one of the reason
that's been given for the delay as a
process known horribly as Maxwell
ization in other words allowing those
people who are being referred to and
criticized in the reports to see a draft
of that criticism and allow them then to
respond to it and given the number of
people they have spoken to that it's a
process that has clearly been taking
some time as I say this is the letter
you can see it on the screen here so
running to what six or seven paragraphs
are a couple of hundred words they are
saying that just to give me the specific
dates that they hope to complete the
text of our report in the week
commencing the 18th of April at 2016 it
goes on to say at that point national
security checking of its contents by a
team of officials who will be given
confidential access to the report on
your behalf can begin the estimation is
that that will take a couple of months
because a few paragraphs down it says I
consider that once national security
checking has been completed it should be
possible to agree with you a date for
publication in June or July 2016
